resource.chars:
In this way, by combining each colour with two standard 
colours, we may produce a white equal to the constant white 
The red and yellow colours from (20) to (32) must be combined with green and blue 
[the gr?]eens from (36) to (52) with red and blue, and the blues from (56) to (80) with red 
and green. 
The following is a specimen of an actual series of observations 
made in this way. 
Table III 
Oct 13 1859 Observer(k) 
(X) (Y) (Z) 
18[half](24) + 32[half](44) + 32(68) = W*
17[half](24) + 32[half](44) + 63(80) = W 
18(24) + 32[half](44) + 35(72) = W 
19(24) + 32(44) + 31[half](68) = W* 
19(24) + 30[half] + 35(64) = W 
20(24) + 23(44) + 39(60) = W 
21(24) + 14(44) + 58(56) + W 
22(24) + 42(48) + 29[half](68) = W 
19(24) + 31[half](44) + 33(68) = W* 
16(24) + 28(40) + 32[half](68) = W 
6(24) + 27(36) + 32[half](68) = W 
23(32) + 11[half](44) + 32[half](68) + W 
17(28) + 26(44) + 32[half](68) = W 
20(24) + 33[half](44) + 32[half](68) = W* 
46(20) + 33(44) + 30(68) = W 
The equations marked with an asterisk * are those which 
involve the three standard colours, and since every other 
equation must be compared with them, they must be often 
repeated.
